newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Cricket-Stuart hat-trick key to Australian win.
newsitem.headline: Cricket-Stuart hat-trick key to Australian win.

text.p: Fast bowler Anthony Stuart claimed a hat-trick as Australia salvaged some pride with a thrilling three-wicket victory over Pakistan in their World Series limited overs match on Thursday.
Stuart, playing in only his third one-day match for his country, dismissed Ijaz Ahmed, Mohammad Wasim and wicketkeeper Moin Khan in successive balls as part of a five-wicket haul.

Chasing Pakistan's total of 181 for nine in 50 overs, left-hander Michael Bevan helped steer Australia to 182 for seven with three balls to spare, ending a run of five straight losses in the triangular competition.
Bevan scored an unbeaten and highly controlled 79 from 142 balls to ensure that Stuart's outstanding figures of five for 26 from 10 overs were not wasted.
The lanky New South Wales paceman became only the second Australian bowler -- and the 12th in the world -- to take a hat-trick in a limited overs international.
But the victory came too late for Australia, who failed to qualify for the final as hosts in their worst performance in one-day cricket at home for 17 years in terms of results.
Pakistan and West Indies will face each other in the best-of-three final, starting in Sydney on Saturday.
Given his outstanding innings, it was fitting that Bevan should be responsible for the winning run, even if it came as a leg bye off his pads.

Man of the match Stuart, playing in only his third one-day match for his country, took the first five wickets to fall in the space of 14 deliveries at a miserly cost of just one run in a devastating early burst.
In his sixth over with the new ball, he lured Ijaz and Wasim to edge faint catches to wicketkeeper Ian Healy before Moin deflected a thicker edge to Australia captain Mark Taylor at first slip.
Opener Inzamam-ul-Haq smashed five fours on his way to a hard-hitting 64 to bolster Pakistan's total after they slumped to 29 for five.
Stuart's hat-trick was the first by an Australian in a one-day international since fast bowler Bruce Reid in Sydney in January 1986.
